name: Lateral Breathing
startPosition: Active rest, seated, or standing. Hands wrapped around the lower half of the sides of the rib cage.
breathAction: Inhale: Breathe in deeply through the nose to fill the lungs with air. Notice the rib cage naturally expands laterally and the fingers spread apart. Exhale: Slowly breathe out through the mouth to empty the lungs and return to the start position. Notice the rib cage naturally contract inward and the fingers come closer together.
goals: Mobilize the thoracic spine and rib cage
watchPoints: Loss of neutral spine or pelvis
Tension in the neck and shoulders
Little or no movement of the fingers with the breath
Excessive scapulae elevation
variations: Eyes closed to focus on breath connection
Breathe in/out with stages (shallow, deep, deeper)

name: Diaphragmatic Breathing
startPosition: Active rest, seated, or standing. Hands resting on the abdomen.
breathAction: Inhale: Breathe in deeply through the nose to fill the lungs and expand the abdomen out into the hands Exhale: Slowly breathe out through the mouth to empty the lungs and draw the abdomen away from the hands • Excessive flaring of the rib cage
goals: Aids recruitment of the deep core stability muscles, particularly pelvic floor and transverse abdominis
Aids with stress reduction and management of anxiety
watchPoints: Excessive flaring of the rib cage
Loss of neutral spine or pelvis
Tension in the neck and shoulders
Little or no movement of the fingers with the breath
Excessive scapulae elevation
variations: Vary the start position to increase the effect of gravity on the load e.g. quadruped position
Eyes closed to focus on breath connection
Breathe in/out with stages (shallow, deep, deeper)

name: Core Activation
startPosition: Active rest, seated, or standing. Place the index fingers approximately one inch medially and inferiorly to the ASIS
contraindications: Overactive or hypertonic pelvic floor clients: shift the focus to the relaxation of these muscles
breathAction: Inhale: Lengthen the spine Exhale: Contract the pelvic floor muscles to draw them in and up toward the body. Notice the gentle contraction of the muscles underneath the fingertips. Inhale: Fully relax the pelvic floor muscles. Notice the muscles underneath the fingertips soften.
goals: Strengthen deep core stability muscles, such as pelvic floor and transverse abdominis
Coordinate breath and deep core stability engagement
Introduce one of the key principles of Pilates
watchPoints: Loss of neutral spine or pelvis
Overactivation of the superficial abdominal muscles and bracing
Doming of the abdominal muscles
Overaction / gripping of the adductors or gluteals
A bearing down or pushing out sensation reported
Holding breath
Tension in the neck and shoulders
variations: Vary the start position: reducing the effects of gravity decreases the load
Decrease the intensity of the contraction
Decrease the duration of the hold

Vary the start position to increase the effect of gravity on the load e.g. quadruped position
